question: Question_01_(a)
statement:
Mark each statement as true or false and give a general explanation (3
and a third points per part). If you decide that a statement is false,
you can give a contradicting example instead. Bear in mind that to mark
a statement true all of its parts must be true.

It is given that a real matrix \emph{A} is a root of the equation
$\displaystyle A^n â A = 0$ with $\displaystyle n > 1$ an integer.
Then it is possible to conclude the following. The size of \emph{A} is
$\displaystyle n \times n$ because by the Cayley - Hamilton theorem
\emph{A} satisfies $\displaystyle p(A) = 0$, with
$\displaystyle p(\lambda)$ being the characteristic polynomial of
\emph{A}. Since it is given that \emph{A} is a root of an \emph{n}-th
degree polynomial, its characteristic polynomial must be of degree
\emph{n} and thus \emph{A} is $\displaystyle n \times n$.
